In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The structure of neon hydrate is similar to that of ice II, which is a new structure of water.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of sets and functions whose underlying sets are compact Hausdorff spaces and whose functions are continuous. This approach provides a framework for the study of quantum theory that is independent of any particular mathematical structure, such as vector spaces or Hilbert spaces.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoan species, which allowed us to compare the genome and transcriptome of a parasitic cnidarian to that of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian is accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings may provide a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs against SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The stability of global grain trade and international grain prices is crucial for the food security of the world’s poor. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices will be compromised by the middle of the 21st century. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, it is difficult to quantify this partitioning because of the large number of species involved. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and those that survive the crisis will likely face a long road to recovery. We also find that many small businesses are uncertain about the length of the crisis, and that those with longer-lasting disruptions are more likely to close. Finally, we find that many small businesses are likely to apply for the new federal loans, but that they anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total load is far less than expected. This is due to the fast fragmentation of the debris into smaller particles, which are then transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris and the importance of the size distribution of the floating debris. It also provides a baseline for future studies of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. We determined the age of a presolar silicon carbide grain, which condensed in the interstellar medium, and found that it is older than the age of the Solar System. This result has important implications for our understanding of the formation of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. Here, we show that the evolution of domestication and the evolution of allonursing both increase the amount of energy available to the mother and that this increase in energy availability correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is an important finding because it suggests that the evolution of sociality may be more important in the evolution of the placenta than previously thought. This is a major advance in our understanding of the evolution of placentation.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the substantia nigra and the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the main form of α-syn that is thought to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The vascular endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines the blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected by a network of communication. This paper describes the structure of the communication network and its properties. The network is found to be highly efficient in the transmission of information, and is characterized by a small-world configuration. This structure is found to be critical for the control of vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic, responding to it, and planning for the future. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and provide examples of how the data can be used to inform decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers, and we hope that it will be useful to many others.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are thus the focus of intense research. In this work, we have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a molecular basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the potential for the microbiome to influence the composition of the microbiome is not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products that could influence the composition of the microbiome. These results support the idea that the gut microbiome is a dynamic system that is influenced by the activities of the host and the microbes within the microbiome. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to influence the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social rank and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple material phases into composite structures, which are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The synthesized structures are found to exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular material distributions. Within the structures, different materials seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can inspire the design of mechanical structures with complex and programmable responses.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the life span of humans. The hemoglobin system is also a major determinant of the life span of mice. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans and mice. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in erythroid cells and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We also show that IGF2BP1 mediates the loss of BCL11A, a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin expression, and that this loss of BCL11A is responsible for the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important in the development of aging and disease. Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that this resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also identified a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment, which involves combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction. This strategy may be useful for cancer treatment in the clinic. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Our study shows that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving the activation of the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ channel complex. Our findings may help to improve the safety of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forest bird populations. We also show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the need for continued monitoring of bird populations and forest conditions to assess the effectiveness of the NWFP.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the rational design of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. The history of Lake Malawi is a window into the evolution of the climate and biota of the tropical African continent. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability. The record shows dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record also reveals a dramatic shift in the hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The record also shows that the climate was drier than today before 800 ka, and that water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT, high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record, and from 800 to 100 ka, a deep, often overfilled lake occupied the basin, indicating a wetter climate. These highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and circadian rhythms have not been studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces alertness, and delays the circadian clock, compared with reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event that has been attributed to a bolide impact. However, the exact nature of the impactor is still debated. Here we show that the osmium isotope composition of sediments and magnetic grains from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial impact. In addition, we show that the ejecta from the YDB are 1.5-Ga rocks from the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results provide further support for the impact hypothesis of the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but that its expression is not essential for the development of tolerance. We also show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery. These findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetle evolution remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding and the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls. These results provide insights into the evolution of beetles and the origins of plant feeding. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origins of plant feeding. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of large-scale experiments.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele. APOE is a major component of the brain’s waste clearance system, and we show here that APOE is critical for the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is responsible for normal synaptic turnover and turnover of senescent synapses. We propose that APOE4 may increase AD risk by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may enhance their vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. Our findings may help to explain the increased AD risk of APOE4 and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, it is difficult to form the stable, hexagonal close-packed phase of iron at the core conditions. This is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. We demonstrate that the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more stable than the hexagonal close-packed phase, and thus is more likely to be the first phase to nucleate. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to be composed of the bcc phase, which is a solid with a different structure from the liquid.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use leads to reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings have important implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for developing effective treatment for marijuana addiction.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also one of the most complex cognitive skills. Here we show that deep learning models, which are known to excel at pattern recognition, can capture much of the neural and behavioral variance associated with comprehending natural language. This suggests that the human brain may use similar mechanisms to process language as it does to process other visual and auditory information. We also find that the architecture of the model appears to be a strong predictor of its neural fit. These results provide a computational framework for understanding the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is not clear whether it is stable, in the sense that it is well-conditioned. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been characterized by a large number of studies that claim to show that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence for this claim. It is shown that the experiment’s design is flawed in a way that has been overlooked in the literature. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of it has been debated for even longer. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of a pathogen that is associated with the most severe form of leprosy, and show that it is closely related to the leprosy bacillus, which is the cause of the milder forms of the disease. This study provides insight into the evolution of the leprosy bacillus and may help in the development of new therapies for leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the basis of thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of matter. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of an isolated quantum system is completely determined by the dynamics of its entropy. This result is valid for both interacting and noninteracting systems, and it is exact in the quasiparticle scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid response to combat the disease. In this study, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant animal model. These properties make it a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of this disease.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different species have different numbers of neurons. This study shows that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons. The most dramatic increases in neuron numbers occurred with the evolution of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent scaling of brain neurons. The other two major increases in neuron numbers happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is controlled by a network of proteins that regulate the activity of the cyclin-dependent kinases that drive the cell cycle. In this study, we show that a protein that is involved in the regulation of the cell cycle, cyclin-dependent kinase 1, is also involved in the regulation of the cell cycle in the cell cycle. This finding has implications for our understanding of the cell cycle and cancer.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of the filament and severing it. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that it is a general mechanism that is used by other proteins to boost their ability to sever highly connected filament networks.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward in our understanding of the history of human populations in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that emotional contagion is not possible in the real world. Our results suggest that emotional contagion is possible in the real world, and that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The vast majority of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) in cells contain thousands of codons, each of which is translated into a different amino acid. However, there are many instances where the ribosome encounters a codon that is not translated, but instead undergoes a chemical modification. In this work, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in a manner that can alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the function of Ψ in cells and may also be relevant to the development of mRNA-based therapeutics. (Show more)

This study shows that a sense of the things one does in life being worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. This finding has implications for understanding the role of worthwhile activities in promoting health and well-being, and in the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in the fossil record. Here, we use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a consequence of the aquatic environment, rather than a release from size constraints.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold, and it replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C than at 33 °C, and that this temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. Here we show that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used both for twitching motility and as a sensor for surface contact. This dual function is important for the pathogen to sense the environment and adapt its behavior to the local conditions.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of peer-reviewed studies that evaluates, for the first time to our knowledge on a global scale, the exposure of surface waters to particularly toxic agricultural insecticides. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of animals in the spread of COVID-19. This is a critical step toward mitigating the impact of the pandemic. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed. We propose a new approach to hydropower that is more sustainable and can be implemented in the developing world.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary component of the pathological process. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of Aβ in the brain, and that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammation in AD. This is a significant finding, since it suggests that the accumulation of Aβ within neurons is a key event in the development of AD, and may be a major contributor to the neuroinflammation that is a hallmark of the disease. This finding has important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most controversial. The present study provides new insights into the earliest history of the chicken, which is of great importance for understanding the development of the species.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is complex, with distinct steps on the way to the native state. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps. In this work, we show that a bacterial enzyme that removes the cap of Np4-capped RNAs also decaps those RNAs in response to stress. This enzyme, which is normally inactive under conditions of disulfide stress, is able to decaps Np4-capped RNAs because of a unique mechanism of substrate recognition. This recognition mechanism, which is different from the one used to recognize other 5′ termini, results in the generation of a monophosphorylated RNA 5′ terminus that is required for rapid degradation of the transcript. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria adapt to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also provide a strategy for the treatment of other inflammatory conditions. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can reach a steady state with a power-law distribution of activity. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a material with a large bandgap, which limits its use in electronics and photonics. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be reduced to zero, without phonon instability. This opens up new possibilities for diamond applications in electronics and photonics.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is a significant advance in the fight against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of these peptides and demonstrates their potential as a new class of fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during their journey through the female reproductive tract. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are critical for supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by interacting with glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the rapid binding of VWF to platelets that is triggered by alterations in flow during bleeding. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWF that cause bleeding disorders. The results also suggest that the effects of force on the structure of VWF may be more general than previously thought.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been shown to influence health and disease. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and allows for the identification of previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to advance our understanding of the human microbiome and its impact on health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is capable of providing high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by conducting a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the increased droplet number concentration was canceled out by enhanced evaporation, so the liquid water path was not increased. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. Here we present a method for determining the temperature history of the Earth based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. This method is independent of the isotopic record and provides a means of assessing the accuracy of previous temperature reconstructions. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in many physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The K+ channel KCNK10 (formerly known as KCNK8) is a member of the K+ channel family that is involved in the regulation of blood pressure. We studied the KCNK10 channel and found that it is a unique K+ channel that shows a slow C-type inactivation. We propose that the slow C-type inactivation is a closed state-dependent mechanism that may be involved in the regulation of blood pressure. This study may help to understand the function of the KCNK10 channel. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion and suggests that the malaria parasite is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for quantum computing, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the electronic bandgap can be tuned continuously. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in quantum technologies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remain largely unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple regions of the brain increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and disease. Axin is a key component of the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work may help to understand the evolution of redundant genes in vertebrates.

This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and obesity. The lateral hypothalamus is a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding. Here we show that stimulation of this region induces vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is involved in overeating, as lesions of this circuit in mice prevented the development of overeating. This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is limited. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable manner. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a sustainable agriculture. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

The sense of hearing is a fundamental part of the animal kingdom. It is present in all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. However, the diversity of the auditory organs of these animals is astonishing, and they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its proteinaceous, self-manufactured web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target for the development of vaccines against COVID-19. We engineered the RBD of the Wuhan-Hu-1 strain to improve its manufacturability and immunogenicity. The engineered RBD was presented on a virus-like particle (VLP) and showed enhanced protection against two variants of concern in hamsters. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is caused by mutations in anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), which is also involved in the development of other tissues. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/ALKL signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/ALKL family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. This study provides a link between ALK/ALKL signaling and neural crest development, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the history of plague is poorly understood because of the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a unique window into the formative years of plague. Our results reveal a single lineage of plague that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be useful for understanding the emergence of other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. This work has implications for understanding and countering the rise of right-wing populism.

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in soils. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can increase the amount of C stored in soils, but the magnitude of these effects depends on the type of soil and the management system. We also show that the amount of C stored in soils is related to the amount of C used by the soil microbial community. These results highlight the importance of soil health management practices in increasing the amount of C stored in soils, and the importance of the microbial community in determining the amount of C used by the soil. These findings have implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform the development of strategies to prevent future pandemics.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinators to find the plant. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a convergent evolution of the red nectar trait in two other plants visited by vertebrates. This work suggests that the red nectar trait is a convergently evolved trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical biology of Campanulaceae. (Less)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who lived in present-day Bavaria, Germany. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent and control future zoonotic outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, with dengue virus as the most abundant pathogen. We also identified underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV. Our findings highlight the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using mNGS in resource-scarce settings, which can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to monitor the regional pathogen landscape and identify emerging pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of DNA strands in the 3′ to 5′ direction. This process is carried out by DNA polymerases, enzymes that copy DNA from a template. In humans, the lagging strand is synthesized in the nucleus, and the polymerase responsible for this process is called pol δ. We have developed a unique kinetic assay to study the processivity and stability of pol δ. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the PCNA complex while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring problems in science. In this paper, we describe a method for the in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This is a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Tocilizumab, which is an anti-interleukin-6 receptor antibody, is effective in reducing mortality in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected to be a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also toxic at high concentrations. The ability to control copper levels is therefore important for the survival of fungi. In this work, we demonstrate that the xan BGC, which encodes a family of isocyanide siderophores, binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We also show that xan BGC-derived isocyanides are secreted and have significant metal-dependent antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the control of copper levels and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This is an important discovery, as it suggests that the existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work may also have implications for the treatment of fungal infections. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a key mineral for understanding the conditions under which silica was available to form silicates and other silica-rich minerals. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is shaped by the evolutionary history of the species involved, and that this distribution is changing in response to climate change. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing risk of frost damage.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual transition of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and the support of the development of classic Th1 cells by a subset of Th17 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. This method will enable the rapid production of large numbers of astrocytes, which will be useful for high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will be a powerful tool for ALS research and drug discovery.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now demonstrate that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of gut bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence their vectors to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most iconic and enigmatic features of bird evolution. The presence of a short tail in the earliest members of the clade Pygostylia is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new species of early pygostylian bird from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail and the mosaic nature of morphological evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the interactions between its components. In this paper, we show that one of the components, the stratospheric water vapor, has a significant impact on the climate system. This is important because the stratospheric water vapor is difficult to measure, and it is not a component that is often considered in climate models.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most striking features of the animal kingdom. In this study, we describe a mechanism that allows for the evolution of color in vertebrates. We show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of color in anurans, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This work also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells are often exposed to hypoxic conditions, which are associated with the development of cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of an m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cell-like. This increase is mediated by HIF-dependent expression of ALKBH5, which increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, which may contribute to the development of breast cancer stem cells. This may be a mechanism by which breast cancer cells adapt to hypoxic conditions. This may be important for understanding the development of breast cancer and for developing new therapies. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future, and may be particularly useful for the study of medieval manuscripts. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Ma, and the extinction interval is 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was rapid. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

The nuclear retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the regulation of inflammation. However, the molecular mechanism of how RORα regulates inflammation is still unclear. Here, we demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This may help explain the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 81.9 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the pseudo–noble-gas elements (Ni, Pd, and Pt) are electron acceptors, while the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) are electron donors, and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) are electron donors. This work is a step toward the development of a predictive model for the behavior of atoms under pressure.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of global fire activity over the past century, and that these are likely to continue to play a major role in shaping future fire regimes. However, our results suggest that, in some regions, climate change may be the dominant driver of fire activity in the future. This may have important implications for the future of carbon storage in terrestrial ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbial communities. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the persistence of a symbiont in a specific niche. This glycan is released by host cells just before dusk, when the squid is most likely to be foraging. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to control the composition of their symbiont communities.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the latent structure of text data is often unknown. We introduce a method to identify the topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of text data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30 to 60% of Europe’s population, is one of the most devastating events in human history. This epidemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Our study shows that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This finding challenges the traditional view of the Black Death as a single event and suggests that the disease was introduced into Europe repeatedly, over a period of four centuries. Our results have important implications for our understanding of the history of the Black Death and the spread of plague in the modern world.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss has been shown to have a significant impact on the ecosystem. We show that a virus is responsible for the recent mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common cancers in the world, and the prognosis is poor. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. We show that the antibody is able to target both the expression of IL1RAP on AML cells and IL-1 signaling. This antibody is able to induce antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block IL-1 signaling, and it is able to suppress the proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work may lead to the development of a new class of drugs for the treatment of AML.
