Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a rapid growth of the population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened from different directions. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward in our understanding of the history of human populations in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but are often ignored in favor of more sophisticated models and remote sensing. We show that the information contained in crop expert surveys can be used to develop a continuous, probabilistic measure of crop status that is more accurate and precise than official forecasts. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by providing earlier and more accurate predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor crop status and detect anomalies in real time. This is a key step towards the development of a global network of “people as sensors” that can provide continuous and accurate information on crop status.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is unique to humans. It is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms, including the ability to maintain information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the excitability of neurons can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. Here, we present a model of the evolutionary trajectory of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection, which is followed by a series of rate equilibria. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of plastid genomes and the origin of eukaryotes.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results provide a valuable tool for risk assessment and adaptation planning in the region.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal, in the form of a glass of sand, water, and copper, which was formed at the instant of the first nuclear explosion. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the history of the universe and the origin of quasicrystals.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which the energy of the sun is captured and converted to chemical energy. The biosynthesis of chlorophyll, the central pigment of photosynthesis, is a highly evolved and highly productive pathway in nature. This pathway is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is essential for photosynthesis. The biosynthesis of the other is required for growth. Here we describe the evolution of these two enzymes, and discuss their roles in photosynthesis. (C) 2013 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the development of neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in a phase-specific manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. (PsycINFO Dataset)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most severe droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. Our results have important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large genetic component. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal pathways that lead to the core symptoms of autism. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the convergence of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal pathways that lead to autism. This study also provides a potential approach for the development of behavioral therapies for autism.

This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the general public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in this regard. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that humans are more sensitive to negative information than positive information, and that this sensitivity is reflected in the news content that is most likely to be consumed by the general public. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disease characterized by a constellation of symptoms that include bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the components of the store-operated Ca2+ channel complex, STIM1 and ORAI1, can cause Stormorken syndrome. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and related conditions, and suggest potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of protein aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the ability of neurons to respond to the presence of aggregates. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of lysosomes, demonstrating that the release of aggregates is an important element of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading and the potential for therapeutic intervention in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is thought to be an important factor in the maintenance of bat-borne viruses. However, the immunosuppressive protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, was found to be a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the conversion of leukotriene A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the origin of the influenza virus pandemic of 1918, which is thought to have originated from bats. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these vulnerabilities can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies. Thus, we have identified a metabolic pathway that is targetable in cancer, and have developed a strategy for developing more effective cancer therapies. This work has implications for cancer therapy, and for the development of more effective cancer therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that are colocalized with mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other cell types. This suggests that the inclusion bodies that form in ALS are the result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. This device can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the history of life, and the study of the evolution of plants is of great importance. The Cretaceous is also a time when the Earth was very different from the one we live on today. This research focuses on a plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to today’s water lilies. This plant is an important link in the evolution of plants and may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and this rate is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is used to project the rate of sea level rise over the next 25 y and the end of the century. The results are consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key component of the mechanistic picture for many enzymes. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into both structure and chemical dynamics, including the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the reaction mechanism is key to understanding why indole, an isostere of the natural substrate, reacts, while benzimidazole, does not. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a severe and poorly understood disease. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV, is also effective against MERS-CoV in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is an important step forward in the development of a treatment for MERS.

The provision of a single glycan by the host to its symbiotic partner is a mechanism that has been proposed to regulate the activities of a variety of microbial communities. Here, we show that this glycan is provisioned only at night, and that its catabolism is required for the maintenance of a specific symbiosis. This glycan may therefore be used as a molecular clock in the mutualism between E. scolopes and V. fischeri. This glycan may also be used as a molecular clock in the mutualism between E. scolopes and V. fischeri.

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed. The experiments were conducted in three school districts, in three states, and in three countries. The results are consistent across settings and suggest that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. This has important implications for the future of education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can be bypassed by pol II in a sequence-dependent manner. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. It also provides a foundation for the development of DNA alkylation-based cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV infection. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This paper provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the global effort to reduce the environmental impacts of food production and to improve population health. The results are robust to a range of potential confounding factors, including the effect of the experimental intervention on other aspects of the cafeteria environment, and to the possibility that diners may have been influenced by the presence of other diners who had made a different choice. The results are also robust to the possibility that diners may have been influenced by the presence of other diners who had made a different choice. The results are robust to the possibility that diners may have been influenced by the presence of other diners who had made a different choice.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing different oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in cancer. It also provides a resource for the cancer research community. The data are available for download, and the methods are described in detail in the manuscript. The data are a valuable resource for the cancer research community. The methods are described in detail in the manuscript.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to have a number of mechanisms for immune evasion, including the ability to suppress the activity of the interferon response. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is involved in immune suppression. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, as well as a second interface that is unique to SARS-CoV. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which SARS-CoV-2 may be able to evade the immune system and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening illness. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are surrounded by them: the association between the color of a car and the likelihood that we will buy it, the association between the number of calories in a food and our likelihood of eating it, the association between the number of friends we have on Facebook and our likelihood of becoming depressed. We are also surrounded by associations that we do not want to see: the association between a person’s race and their likelihood of being stopped by the police, the association between a person’s race and their likelihood of being arrested, the association between a person’s race and their likelihood of being killed by the police. We need tools for assessing the strength of associations that we want to see and for avoiding the associations that we do not want to see. This paper describes some recent advances in this area.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordination of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of fibroblasts into vascular ECs. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular regeneration. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK has led to the identification of a number of additional ligands. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also provides a model system for studying the role of RTKs in human disease.

β-cell dysfunction is one of the main molecular bases for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule of innate immune response, plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a loss of nuclear factor of activated T cells 1 (NFAT) and impaired GSIS, leading to T2D. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses, which are genetically distinct and cause different diseases. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of viral RNA segments that are in close proximity. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that control the packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also provide a starting point for the development of new strategies to control influenza. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that involves the activation of atheroprone phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes in ECs. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents, and demonstrated that this channel is also involved in the avoidance behavior. This study provides insights into the molecular targets of natural repellents, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short, the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the ongoing bleaching event, which is driven by climate change. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the energy limitation of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to better predict the fate of coral reefs in a warming world.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that protects the body from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a dynamic tissue that can be influenced by the microbiome. We also identify a mechanism that can link intestinal tumors to the microbiome and lead to a loss of epithelial barrier function. Our work highlights the importance of maintaining the homeostasis between the epithelium and the microbiome to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work may lead to the development of new strategies to treat intestinal tumors and restore epithelial barrier function.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse and die from the disease. We show that treatment with chemotherapy enhances the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells, which may contribute to the development of breast cancer stem cells. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. These results may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a reduction in Southern Hemisphere precipitation and a subsequent collapse of the Southern Hemisphere summer monsoons. However, this attribution is based on a single paleoclimate proxy, and the timing of the change is uncertain. Here, we show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions at the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is consistent with a poleward shift in the westerlies and a reduction in Southern Hemisphere precipitation, and that the eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which is known to reduce the strength of the westerlies. This suggests that the Mount Takahe eruptions may have led to a poleward shift in the westerlies and a reduction in Southern Hemisphere precipitation, which in turn may have led to the collapse of the Southern Hemisphere summer monsoons. This is a unique link between volcanism and climate that has not been considered before.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity, food security, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that fishing is most intense in regions where rivers are already under stress from other human activities. This suggests that efforts to protect biodiversity in rivers may also protect the livelihoods of people who depend on fisheries for food and income. Our data can be used to inform the design of policies to improve the sustainability of freshwater fisheries and to protect the food security of vulnerable populations.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are a promising solution for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate effectively, and the reasons for this are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the signaling pathways known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new approach to understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the genome as a whole. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, while others are highly active. These results are similar to those found in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the distribution of recombination across the genome may be a conserved feature of eukaryotic evolution.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The present study provides a method for identifying and validating resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The method is based on the analysis of metabolic imaging, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total neuronal activity. The method is noninvasive, does not require the use of contrast agents, and is not affected by the presence of metal implants. The method can be used to study the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. Our findings may have implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in health and disease.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive therapy could prevent the development of diabetes complications. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years after the DCCT, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. In this study, we identified a role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the drug sensitivity of TNBC cells. We show that FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases the activity of the mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin pathways. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds, and the fruit is a major source of food flavor. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of the volatiles produced in tomato fruit are not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato volatiles and will be of interest to researchers in the field. (Less)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our work has important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the precise arrangement of these neurons is critical for understanding the function of MEC. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the spatial organization of neurons in MEC is more complex than previously thought. Our results suggest that the spatial organization of neurons in MEC is more complex than previously thought. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can function as an interplant flowering signal, which is able to synchronize flowering of host and parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of how flowering is controlled in plants.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to gauge the quality of their connections with others, and by third-party listeners to gauge the quality of connections between people. This finding has implications for our understanding of social connection, and for the design of technologies that can help people feel more connected.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the SAN and plays a key role in the regulation of the electrical activity of these cells. Our studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells, which links the content of Ca2+ stores with the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern the electrical activity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. Here, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants is beneficial in protecting against insect attack. We demonstrate that the accumulation of Si in rice plants is dependent on the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect plants against insect attack. This study may help to elucidate the function of Si in plant physiology and may lead to the development of new strategies for the protection of plants against insect attack. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the resolution of inflammation. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is unique to humans. It is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms, including the ability to maintain information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the excitability of neurons can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the location of the attachment site of the biomolecule to the DNA nanostructure is important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. These results will be useful for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and other organisms.

The world’s largest lakes are often the most valuable and threatened ecosystems on the planet. We show that the nutrient inputs to these lakes are highly variable, depending on the size of the watershed draining to the lake. We also show that the smallest watersheds are the most important contributors of nutrients to the lake, and that these nutrients are more bioavailable than those from larger watersheds. This suggests that the nutrient inputs to the lake are more likely to fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone, where the lakes are most valuable. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication, and suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on these watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a potential that is biased toward rare minima. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are robust to environmental fluctuations.

This study provides a detailed description of the effects of an antibody against the NMDA receptor on the brain’s electrical activity. This information will be useful for understanding the mechanisms of action of this antibody and for developing new treatments for the disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and it is important to understand how the Earth system responds to such events. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in atmospheric CO2. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and to an increase in the stratification of the ocean. These results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt climate change.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification has reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that most certified areas still contain substantial amounts of forest. We also show that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on deforestation, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results also suggest that certification may be a useful tool for reducing fire, but that more research is needed to understand the causal impact of certification on fire. Our results are important for the future of certification as a tool for reducing tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and can be used to study its function in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potential drug target for human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animal diversity. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, sex is determined by multiple interacting genes. Here we show that the multiple sex determination alleles in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii interact to produce a modular system of sex-linked traits. This system of modular traits provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct types of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptor cells and by the environment. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which is a key ROS source, impact the generation of ROS and the photodegradation of lipofuscin, a major source of oxidative damage in the retina. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, which is characterized by accumulation of lipofuscin. Our results suggest that the intracellular levels of iron may be a therapeutic target for this disease. (Less)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also common. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human behavior.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies. Thus, this work provides a framework for the development of more effective cancer therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is an important finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern farm machinery is responsible for the vast majority of soil compaction, which is a major threat to soil productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction, which is now a major threat to soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, which shows that 20% of arable land is at risk of chronic subsoil compaction. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a 130-million-year-old footprint in the Morrison Formation of North America. This footprint is the oldest evidence of subsoil compaction and may have been caused by the sauropod’s weight.
